Activities with smallholder cattle keepers
Activities with smallholder women and men cattle keepers were aimed at increasing their capacity on, and improving their attitude towards, cattle AI. The activities comprised training on beef cattle breeds, breeding and AI, examining and treating reproductive diseases, as well as exposure to cattle AI through demonstration farms.
Training of cattle keepers on cattle breeds, breeding and AI
Training on cattle breeding, breeds and artificial insemination was achieved both through community workshop and trainings held within farmer groups. The training were a day in length and conducted by an expert team from NIAS (for the community workshops (Marshall and Le Thi Thanh 2023a) and by the Son La sub-DAH team for the farmer-group members (Son La Sub-department of Livestock Production, Animal Health and Fisheries 2024). All trainings were designed to be interactive, with group discussions and question and answer sessions. Topics included cattle breeds and their performance, the cattle reproductive cycle, how to select good breeding animals, cow heat detection, and artificial insemination, as well as taking care of pregnant and lactating cows. Materials supporting the training included posters (which remained in cultural centers (CGIAR Research Program on Livestock 2021), and training manuals which were given to each participant (Le et al. 2024 ), see Figures 2 and 3. Particular attention was paid to ensure that both women and men cattle keepers attended the training, though specifically inviting both women and men within households and ensuring that the training location was in a centralized and easy to access location. In addition to the women and men cattle keepers, local animal health care workers attended the training as well.
The respondents were very appreciative of the training, and noted that training of this nature had rarely (If ever) been offered before (Marshall and Le Thi Thanh 2023a).

Activities with artificial insemination service providers
Activities involving both women and men artificial inseminators and from Kinh, Thai and H'Mong ethnic groups aimed to equip them with high-quality skills in artificial insemination (AI) techniques, whilst ensuring AI service delivery was both professional and profitable. Activities comprised comprehensive training in the technical aspects of AI, alongside guidance on business operations. A cooperative was established to facilitate shared access to semen storage facilities, and partnerships were forged with semen suppliers to ensure a steady supply of quality genetics. Additionally, AI service providers were given booklets to track insemination procedures, monitor success rates, and assess the profitability of their services, enhancing both technical proficiency and business sustainability.
Training in the cattle AI technique, certification, and follow-on support
Training of women and men veterinary (animal health) workers and veterinarians on the technique of cattle artificial insemination was achieved through a 21 day training course (Marshall and Huyen 2023b). The course comprised both theoretical and practical sessions. Topics covered during the theoretical sessions included cattle reproduction, cattle breeding, semen including sexed semen, synchronization, heat detection, AI equipment and technique, pregnancy detection, embryo transfer, and reproductive diseases and their treatment. All theoretical sessions were interactive and all trainees were provided with a training manual (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2020a). The practical sessions comprised: examination and practice AI using cow uterus from different culled animals (heifers, cows etc.) provided by the slaughterhouse (Figure 5); practice AI on live cows destined for slaughter; on-farm examination of cows, synchronization and artificial insemination (Figure 6), as well as treatment of reproductive diseases. At the end of the course all trainees were examined for their skills on AI (practical) as well as theoretical understanding (oral examination). Those successfully completing the course were registered with the Animal Husbandry Research and Development Center for Mountainous Zone (ARDC - NIAS) and Issued with a certificate.
Following training, on-going support until project end was provided to the AI service providers through interactions, including field-visits, messages in Zalo group, phone-calls, and video calls, with the AI trainers. (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2024). This on-going support was important in ensuring the AI

Business models studies were undertaken to consider different approaches to sustainable AI service delivery within Son La Province (Bravo et al. 2023a; Bravo et al. 2023b). A key recommendation from the study was a cattle AI service providers cooperative, which would serve multiple purposes including supporting operational capacity, reducing input and equipment costs, acting as a liaison between providers and various stakeholders (such as local authorities, NGOs, input suppliers, and farmers), disseminating technical knowledge related to cattle AI, Improved breeds, and animal husbandry practices. Based on this recommendation a beef-cattle AI service providers co-operative was established, which has played a core role in this model.
The AI co-operative established comprised four members, two men and two women, belonging to the Kinh, Thai and H'Mong ethnic groups. The co-operative leader is the communal veterinary of Hat Lot town, who was an established cattle AI service provider in Mai Son District. Two other members are
Page 10 of 19

communal veterinarians of Chieng Chung and Chieng Luong communes who wanted to become AI service providers for both cows and sows. The fourth member is a director of a beef cooperative and started to do cattle AI service in Muong Bon commune. The membership size of the co-operative was determined based on expected demand for cattle AI within the Chan-Henh project sites. As demand increases, or if the approach is scaled to neighboring sites, the number of members within the co- operative could increase
All co-operative members agreed to, and signed, a common operation regulation. The aim was to ensure that the co-operative supported all members, but with members accruing individual benefits. The regulations covered issues such as: assignment of operational sub-regions assigned to each member, to ensure manageable travel distances; charges for services for uniform pricing; the semen sources to be used; sharing of group costs, for example, shipping fees; recording practices; and other practices such as advise given to farmers on cattle reproduction and AI.
A large (35-litre) liquid nitrogen tank was provided to, and managed through, the co-operative lead. Specially the lead would be responsible for importing liquid nitrogen on a weekly basis and distributing to other co-operative members, as well as semen importation as required, with payment received to cover all costs.
Additionally each members was provided with a small (3 litre) liquid nitrogen tank (to be able to transport semen on the back on motorbikes), an insemination gun (CIDR Bovine applicator) and some consumables (insemination gel, gloves, 5ml cylinders, 18 gauge needles; and synchronization hormones  PGF2 (OvuprostTM), Ovurelin) to help them launch their AI provision businesses.
On semen, experts from NIAS connected the AI co-operative members with four input suppliers for cattle AI (semen and tools) including both state and private ones. The members considered the price, breeds of available semen, way of trading, and the convenience in receiving the inputs. Based on this an individual supplier was selected. Semen is purchased by the co=operative lead as needed, and stored under liquid nitrogen until required by a co-operative member for insemination.
The signing of the common operation regulations and distribution of equipment was undertaken during a workshop (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2024). At this time the AI co-operative members were also introduced to farmers, village heads, leaders of communes, and representatives from the District DARD, provincial DARD; and Agricultural Service Centre.
Communications within the co-operative is facilitated by a Zalo group comprising the AI members as well as NIAS experts on artificial insemination. Discussions have included the sharing of successful AI stories, AI and synchronization issues, diagnosis and treatment of reproductive issues (including by sharing videos and photos), jointly working together to perform AIs when many are being undertaken within a commune, amongst others.
Financial management of the co-operative has been as follows. For the first three months, the project supported the co-operative through the provision of liquid nitrogen, payment of half of the semen and semen transport fees (with the other half paid by the farmer group members receiving the AI), and coverage of re-insemination fees. After this time-period, the co-operative leader has been responsible for purchasing liquid nitrogen, when reimbursement from the co-operative members based on the volumes they use. Note the liquid nitrogen price to the members was set at cost-price, but compensating for liquid nitrogen loss from the main reservoir over time.
Future activities planned by the co-operative include registration at District level, continued promotion of AI, and potentially linking with other livestock development programs to provide AI services. Recording tools
To further support the AI service providers, recording booklets were created to track both artificial inseminations and business profitability. These booklets, developed in both Vietnamese and English, are referred to as the AI Service Provider Recording Booklet on Service Provision (Marshall and Le Thi 2023 c,d) and the AI Service Provider Recording Booklet for Accounting (Marshall and Le Thi, 2023 e,f).
The AI Service Provision booklet enables providers to monitor all activities related to a specific cow and its insemination (Figure 7). It includes detailed records of the client, cow, and AI-related activities, along with dates for follow-up visits and outcomes of the inseminations. Each cow that undergoes insemination has a dedicated double-page spread, facilitating easy visualization of the activities conducted for that cow, such as synchronization, heat detection, insemination, and pregnancy detection. This recording booklet empowers AI service providers to track their clients effectively, plan follow-up visits with ease, and evaluate the outcomes of the artificial insemination process.

Strengthening linkages between the cattle keepers and the AI service providers
Connecting cattle keepers with AI service providers was a crucial aspect of promoting the adoption of cattle artificial insemination. This connection was fostered between farmer groups and AI service providers by having the providers in training sessions on AI (Son La sub-DAH, 2024). Additionally, these service providers took part in village meetings to discuss the benefits of utilizing AI in cattle farming, which helped promote their businesses and offered farmers with a reliable resource for livestock services (https://www.cgiar.org/news-events/news/promoting-the-adoption-of-saplings-innovations- through-village-sharing-events/). A Zalo group has been formed that consists of cattle keepers, AI service providers, AI experts, and researchers from NIAS. This group shares information related to cattle artificial insemination, including topics like cow births, calf care, management of pregnant and lactating cows, and post-calving treatment issues. The discussions are supplemented with pictures and short videos.
The AI service providers expressed that these linkages were essential for building relationships with potential clients, while farmers appreciated knowing their service provider and having direct contact with them.
Gender considerations
Women's contributions to the agricultural sector are crucial, and one of the key objectives of the Chan Henh project was to enhance their inclusion (Atieno et al. 2023). Introduction
Agriculture is central to the economy and livelihoods in Vietnams Son La Province, where the mountainous terrain and tropical climate support the cultivation of crops like maize, rice, tea, and various fruits, which are key for both local consumption and trade. Livestock, particularly beef cattle, is an essential component of the agricultural system, providing income through the sale of animals, manure for soil fertility, and draft power for farming. For smallholder farmers, beef cattle production plays a crucial role in their mixed farming systems, contributing significantly to household income and food security. However, farmers face several challenges that limit productivity and profitability. These include limited access to improved cattle genetics, which could enhance meat production, and the prevalence of cattle diseases, which affect herd health and growth. Additionally, the availability of high- quality feed is often constrained, especially during the dry season, impacting cattle growth. Profitability is further hindered by market fluctuations and a lack of organized value chains, which reduce the farmers' ability to secure stable and favorable prices for their cattle. Addressing these challenges through better breeding practices, disease control, improved feeds, and enhanced market access would greatly benefit the farmers and enhance the economic potential of beef cattle production in the region. This has been the aim of the CGIAR Initiative Sustainable Animal Productivity for Livelihoods, Nutrition and Gender Inclusion (SAPLING) operating under the local project name of 'Chan- Henh' in Son La Province (Atieno et al. 2023).
Page 4 of 19

Under Chan-Henh a model was developed to promote use of artificial insemination (AI) in beef cattle. This model was developed in response to concerns from cattle farmers in Son La regarding the difficulty of finding quality breeding cattle and their high price (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2021a). AI has the advantage over natural mating of improving access to high quality genetics, reducing disease spread, and being cost-effective (in comparison to smallholders keeping their own bull). The adoption of beef cattle AI in Son La has traditionally been low (Hammond et al. 2010) due to both the lack of artificial insemination service providers, particularly in more remote locations, as well as lack of farmers awareness on the advantages of the technology (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2021a).
The model to promote the use of beef cattle AI presented here works with women and men AI service providers, women and men beef-cattle keepers, and partners including the Son La Department of Animal Health and Production, Mai Son Department of Agriculture and Rural Development, Mai Son Agricultural Service Center, and Chieng Chung, Chieng Luong, Muong Bon and Hat Lot Communal People Committees. It was tested in the Mai-Son District of Son La Province, where Chan-Henh operates. The model has been successful in both creating business opportunities in AI service provision as well as promoting AI adopting by smallholder cattle keepers, and is recommended for scaling to other locations within Son La Province and northwest Vietnam more broadly.
The Chan-Henh approach
The Chan-Henh project takes an integrated approach to improving beef cattle production and marketing, comprising: capacity building of farmers and service providers on innovations for improved beef cattle genetics, health-care and feeding; a farmers-groups approach for collective action, including on input acquisition and marketing; gender accommodative and transformative approaches to ensure innovation access and benefit is equitable; and a component to Improve nutrition of the producing households (Otieno et al. 2023). It also addresses pig production and marketing, including promotion of pig AI: the pig AI work will be reported separately.
Chan-Henh was Implemented between 2023 and 2024, within four target communes of the Mai Son District (Ching Chung , Ching Lng, Mng Bon and Ht Lt). It was funded through the One CGIAR Initiative Sustainable Animal Productivity for Livelihoods, Nutrition and Gender Inclusion (SAPLING). Permission to undertake the project was granted by the People's Committee of Son La Province on March 25th 2023 according to Decision No. 963/UBND-NC.
The project was co-designed and co-implemented with partners and stakeholders. CGIAR partners included the Alliance of Bioversity International and CIAT (the Alliance) and the International Livestock Research Institute (ILRI) and local partners included the Son La Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (Son La DARD), the Son La Sub-Department of Animal Husbandry (Son La Sub-DAH), the National Institute of Animal Sciences of Vietnam (NIAS), the National Institute of Veterinary Research (NIVR), the Northern Mountainous Agriculture and Forestry Sciences Institute (NOMAFSI), the Vietnam National University of Agriculture (VNUA) and the National institute of Nutrition (NIN).
A key element of Chan-Henh was the use of farmer groups for improved access of the smallholder farmers to input and output markets, as well as being a forum for capacity development and co-create of solutions to issues pertaining to pig and cattle keeping. Given the inefficient function of the existing farmer groups engaged in cattle and pig production in Mai Son District (in terms of economic and financial sustainability, service offers, marketing connection and trading capacity (Cuong et al. 2023), Chan-Henh focused on developing and implementing strategic plans for upgrading the functioning and capacities of the existing farmer groups, and used that lesson to support the establishment and efficient operation of new farmer groups. Since 2023, SAPLING has been assisting eight farmer groups, comprising 120 members.

The model for promotion of beef cattle artificial insemination

The model to promote cattle artificial insemination (AI) in northwest Vietnam involved: (a) building the capacity of smallholder cattle keepers on cattle breeds, breeding and artificial insemination; (b) training AI service providers in both the technical aspects of artificial insemination as well as agri-business skills and organizing these into a co-operative for shared access to centrally-located semen storage facilities; and (c) facilitating linkages between the cattle keepers and the AI service providers. A schema for the model is given in Figure 1 and more details are given below. Various resources supporting implementation of the model are freely available, as summarized in Box 1.

Activities with smallholder cattle keepers
Activities with smallholder women and men cattle keepers were aimed at increasing their capacity on, and improving their attitude towards, cattle AI. The activities comprised training on beef cattle breeds, breeding and AI, examining and treating reproductive diseases, as well as exposure to cattle AI through demonstration farms.
Training of cattle keepers on cattle breeds, breeding and AI
Training on cattle breeding, breeds and artificial insemination was achieved both through community workshop and trainings held within farmer groups. The training were a day in length and conducted by an expert team from NIAS (for the community workshops (Marshall and Le Thi Thanh 2023a) and by the Son La sub-DAH team for the farmer-group members (Son La Sub-department of Livestock Production, Animal Health and Fisheries 2024). All trainings were designed to be interactive, with group discussions and question and answer sessions. Topics included cattle breeds and their performance, the cattle reproductive cycle, how to select good breeding animals, cow heat detection, and artificial insemination, as well as taking care of pregnant and lactating cows. Materials supporting the training included posters (which remained in cultural centers (CGIAR Research Program on Livestock 2021), and training manuals which were given to each participant (Le et al. 2024 ), see Figures 2 and 3. Particular attention was paid to ensure that both women and men cattle keepers attended the training, though specifically inviting both women and men within households and ensuring that the training location was in a centralized and easy to access location. In addition to the women and men cattle keepers, local animal health care workers attended the training as well.
The respondents were very appreciative of the training, and noted that training of this nature had rarely (If ever) been offered before (Marshall and Le Thi Thanh 2023a).

Activities with artificial insemination service providers
Activities involving both women and men artificial inseminators and from Kinh, Thai and H'Mong ethnic groups aimed to equip them with high-quality skills in artificial insemination (AI) techniques, whilst ensuring AI service delivery was both professional and profitable. Activities comprised comprehensive training in the technical aspects of AI, alongside guidance on business operations. A cooperative was established to facilitate shared access to semen storage facilities, and partnerships were forged with semen suppliers to ensure a steady supply of quality genetics. Additionally, AI service providers were given booklets to track insemination procedures, monitor success rates, and assess the profitability of their services, enhancing both technical proficiency and business sustainability.
Training in the cattle AI technique, certification, and follow-on support
Training of women and men veterinary (animal health) workers and veterinarians on the technique of cattle artificial insemination was achieved through a 21 day training course (Marshall and Huyen 2023b). The course comprised both theoretical and practical sessions. Topics covered during the theoretical sessions included cattle reproduction, cattle breeding, semen including sexed semen, synchronization, heat detection, AI equipment and technique, pregnancy detection, embryo transfer, and reproductive diseases and their treatment. All theoretical sessions were interactive and all trainees were provided with a training manual (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2020a). The practical sessions comprised: examination and practice AI using cow uterus from different culled animals (heifers, cows etc.) provided by the slaughterhouse (Figure 5); practice AI on live cows destined for slaughter; on-farm examination of cows, synchronization and artificial insemination (Figure 6), as well as treatment of reproductive diseases. At the end of the course all trainees were examined for their skills on AI (practical) as well as theoretical understanding (oral examination). Those successfully completing the course were registered with the Animal Husbandry Research and Development Center for Mountainous Zone (ARDC - NIAS) and Issued with a certificate.
Following training, on-going support until project end was provided to the AI service providers through interactions, including field-visits, messages in Zalo group, phone-calls, and video calls, with the AI trainers. (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2024). This on-going support was important in ensuring the AI

Business models studies were undertaken to consider different approaches to sustainable AI service delivery within Son La Province (Bravo et al. 2023a; Bravo et al. 2023b). A key recommendation from the study was a cattle AI service providers cooperative, which would serve multiple purposes including supporting operational capacity, reducing input and equipment costs, acting as a liaison between providers and various stakeholders (such as local authorities, NGOs, input suppliers, and farmers), disseminating technical knowledge related to cattle AI, Improved breeds, and animal husbandry practices. Based on this recommendation a beef-cattle AI service providers co-operative was established, which has played a core role in this model.
The AI co-operative established comprised four members, two men and two women, belonging to the Kinh, Thai and H'Mong ethnic groups. The co-operative leader is the communal veterinary of Hat Lot town, who was an established cattle AI service provider in Mai Son District. Two other members are
Page 10 of 19

communal veterinarians of Chieng Chung and Chieng Luong communes who wanted to become AI service providers for both cows and sows. The fourth member is a director of a beef cooperative and started to do cattle AI service in Muong Bon commune. The membership size of the co-operative was determined based on expected demand for cattle AI within the Chan-Henh project sites. As demand increases, or if the approach is scaled to neighboring sites, the number of members within the co- operative could increase
All co-operative members agreed to, and signed, a common operation regulation. The aim was to ensure that the co-operative supported all members, but with members accruing individual benefits. The regulations covered issues such as: assignment of operational sub-regions assigned to each member, to ensure manageable travel distances; charges for services for uniform pricing; the semen sources to be used; sharing of group costs, for example, shipping fees; recording practices; and other practices such as advise given to farmers on cattle reproduction and AI.
A large (35-litre) liquid nitrogen tank was provided to, and managed through, the co-operative lead. Specially the lead would be responsible for importing liquid nitrogen on a weekly basis and distributing to other co-operative members, as well as semen importation as required, with payment received to cover all costs.
Additionally each members was provided with a small (3 litre) liquid nitrogen tank (to be able to transport semen on the back on motorbikes), an insemination gun (CIDR Bovine applicator) and some consumables (insemination gel, gloves, 5ml cylinders, 18 gauge needles; and synchronization hormones  PGF2 (OvuprostTM), Ovurelin) to help them launch their AI provision businesses.
On semen, experts from NIAS connected the AI co-operative members with four input suppliers for cattle AI (semen and tools) including both state and private ones. The members considered the price, breeds of available semen, way of trading, and the convenience in receiving the inputs. Based on this an individual supplier was selected. Semen is purchased by the co=operative lead as needed, and stored under liquid nitrogen until required by a co-operative member for insemination.
The signing of the common operation regulations and distribution of equipment was undertaken during a workshop (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2024). At this time the AI co-operative members were also introduced to farmers, village heads, leaders of communes, and representatives from the District DARD, provincial DARD; and Agricultural Service Centre.
Communications within the co-operative is facilitated by a Zalo group comprising the AI members as well as NIAS experts on artificial insemination. Discussions have included the sharing of successful AI stories, AI and synchronization issues, diagnosis and treatment of reproductive issues (including by sharing videos and photos), jointly working together to perform AIs when many are being undertaken within a commune, amongst others.
Financial management of the co-operative has been as follows. For the first three months, the project supported the co-operative through the provision of liquid nitrogen, payment of half of the semen and semen transport fees (with the other half paid by the farmer group members receiving the AI), and coverage of re-insemination fees. After this time-period, the co-operative leader has been responsible for purchasing liquid nitrogen, when reimbursement from the co-operative members based on the volumes they use. Note the liquid nitrogen price to the members was set at cost-price, but compensating for liquid nitrogen loss from the main reservoir over time.
Future activities planned by the co-operative include registration at District level, continued promotion of AI, and potentially linking with other livestock development programs to provide AI services. Recording tools
To further support the AI service providers, recording booklets were created to track both artificial inseminations and business profitability. These booklets, developed in both Vietnamese and English, are referred to as the AI Service Provider Recording Booklet on Service Provision (Marshall and Le Thi 2023 c,d) and the AI Service Provider Recording Booklet for Accounting (Marshall and Le Thi, 2023 e,f).
The AI Service Provision booklet enables providers to monitor all activities related to a specific cow and its insemination (Figure 7). It includes detailed records of the client, cow, and AI-related activities, along with dates for follow-up visits and outcomes of the inseminations. Each cow that undergoes insemination has a dedicated double-page spread, facilitating easy visualization of the activities conducted for that cow, such as synchronization, heat detection, insemination, and pregnancy detection. This recording booklet empowers AI service providers to track their clients effectively, plan follow-up visits with ease, and evaluate the outcomes of the artificial insemination process.

Strengthening linkages between the cattle keepers and the AI service providers
Connecting cattle keepers with AI service providers was a crucial aspect of promoting the adoption of cattle artificial insemination. This connection was fostered between farmer groups and AI service providers by having the providers in training sessions on AI (Son La sub-DAH, 2024). Additionally, these service providers took part in village meetings to discuss the benefits of utilizing AI in cattle farming, which helped promote their businesses and offered farmers with a reliable resource for livestock services (https://www.cgiar.org/news-events/news/promoting-the-adoption-of-saplings-innovations- through-village-sharing-events/). A Zalo group has been formed that consists of cattle keepers, AI service providers, AI experts, and researchers from NIAS. This group shares information related to cattle artificial insemination, including topics like cow births, calf care, management of pregnant and lactating cows, and post-calving treatment issues. The discussions are supplemented with pictures and short videos.
The AI service providers expressed that these linkages were essential for building relationships with potential clients, while farmers appreciated knowing their service provider and having direct contact with them.
Gender considerations
Women's contributions to the agricultural sector are crucial, and one of the key objectives of the Chan Henh project was to enhance their inclusion (Atieno et al. 2023). Introduction
Agriculture is central to the economy and livelihoods in Vietnams Son La Province, where the mountainous terrain and tropical climate support the cultivation of crops like maize, rice, tea, and various fruits, which are key for both local consumption and trade. Livestock, particularly beef cattle, is an essential component of the agricultural system, providing income through the sale of animals, manure for soil fertility, and draft power for farming. For smallholder farmers, beef cattle production plays a crucial role in their mixed farming systems, contributing significantly to household income and food security. However, farmers face several challenges that limit productivity and profitability. These include limited access to improved cattle genetics, which could enhance meat production, and the prevalence of cattle diseases, which affect herd health and growth. Additionally, the availability of high- quality feed is often constrained, especially during the dry season, impacting cattle growth. Profitability is further hindered by market fluctuations and a lack of organized value chains, which reduce the farmers' ability to secure stable and favorable prices for their cattle. Addressing these challenges through better breeding practices, disease control, improved feeds, and enhanced market access would greatly benefit the farmers and enhance the economic potential of beef cattle production in the region. This has been the aim of the CGIAR Initiative Sustainable Animal Productivity for Livelihoods, Nutrition and Gender Inclusion (SAPLING) operating under the local project name of 'Chan- Henh' in Son La Province (Atieno et al. 2023).
Page 4 of 19

Under Chan-Henh a model was developed to promote use of artificial insemination (AI) in beef cattle. This model was developed in response to concerns from cattle farmers in Son La regarding the difficulty of finding quality breeding cattle and their high price (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2021a). AI has the advantage over natural mating of improving access to high quality genetics, reducing disease spread, and being cost-effective (in comparison to smallholders keeping their own bull). The adoption of beef cattle AI in Son La has traditionally been low (Hammond et al. 2010) due to both the lack of artificial insemination service providers, particularly in more remote locations, as well as lack of farmers awareness on the advantages of the technology (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2021a).
The model to promote the use of beef cattle AI presented here works with women and men AI service providers, women and men beef-cattle keepers, and partners including the Son La Department of Animal Health and Production, Mai Son Department of Agriculture and Rural Development, Mai Son Agricultural Service Center, and Chieng Chung, Chieng Luong, Muong Bon and Hat Lot Communal People Committees. It was tested in the Mai-Son District of Son La Province, where Chan-Henh operates. The model has been successful in both creating business opportunities in AI service provision as well as promoting AI adopting by smallholder cattle keepers, and is recommended for scaling to other locations within Son La Province and northwest Vietnam more broadly.
The Chan-Henh approach
The Chan-Henh project takes an integrated approach to improving beef cattle production and marketing, comprising: capacity building of farmers and service providers on innovations for improved beef cattle genetics, health-care and feeding; a farmers-groups approach for collective action, including on input acquisition and marketing; gender accommodative and transformative approaches to ensure innovation access and benefit is equitable; and a component to Improve nutrition of the producing households (Otieno et al. 2023). It also addresses pig production and marketing, including promotion of pig AI: the pig AI work will be reported separately.
Chan-Henh was Implemented between 2023 and 2024, within four target communes of the Mai Son District (Ching Chung , Ching Lng, Mng Bon and Ht Lt). It was funded through the One CGIAR Initiative Sustainable Animal Productivity for Livelihoods, Nutrition and Gender Inclusion (SAPLING). Permission to undertake the project was granted by the People's Committee of Son La Province on March 25th 2023 according to Decision No. 963/UBND-NC.
The project was co-designed and co-implemented with partners and stakeholders. CGIAR partners included the Alliance of Bioversity International and CIAT (the Alliance) and the International Livestock Research Institute (ILRI) and local partners included the Son La Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (Son La DARD), the Son La Sub-Department of Animal Husbandry (Son La Sub-DAH), the National Institute of Animal Sciences of Vietnam (NIAS), the National Institute of Veterinary Research (NIVR), the Northern Mountainous Agriculture and Forestry Sciences Institute (NOMAFSI), the Vietnam National University of Agriculture (VNUA) and the National institute of Nutrition (NIN).
A key element of Chan-Henh was the use of farmer groups for improved access of the smallholder farmers to input and output markets, as well as being a forum for capacity development and co-create of solutions to issues pertaining to pig and cattle keeping. Given the inefficient function of the existing farmer groups engaged in cattle and pig production in Mai Son District (in terms of economic and financial sustainability, service offers, marketing connection and trading capacity (Cuong et al. 2023), Chan-Henh focused on developing and implementing strategic plans for upgrading the functioning and capacities of the existing farmer groups, and used that lesson to support the establishment and efficient operation of new farmer groups. Since 2023, SAPLING has been assisting eight farmer groups, comprising 120 members.

The model for promotion of beef cattle artificial insemination
Overview
The model to promote cattle artificial insemination (AI) in northwest Vietnam involved: (a) building the capacity of smallholder cattle keepers on cattle breeds, breeding and artificial insemination; (b) training AI service providers in both the technical aspects of artificial insemination as well as agri-business skills and organizing these into a co-operative for shared access to centrally-located semen storage facilities; and (c) facilitating linkages between the cattle keepers and the AI service providers. A schema for the model is given in Figure 1 and more details are given below. Various resources supporting implementation of the model are freely available, as summarized in Box 1.

Activities with smallholder cattle keepers
Activities with smallholder women and men cattle keepers were aimed at increasing their capacity on, and improving their attitude towards, cattle AI. The activities comprised training on beef cattle breeds, breeding and AI, examining and treating reproductive diseases, as well as exposure to cattle AI through demonstration farms.
Training of cattle keepers on cattle breeds, breeding and AI
Training on cattle breeding, breeds and artificial insemination was achieved both through community workshop and trainings held within farmer groups. The training were a day in length and conducted by an expert team from NIAS (for the community workshops (Marshall and Le Thi Thanh 2023a) and by the Son La sub-DAH team for the farmer-group members (Son La Sub-department of Livestock Production, Animal Health and Fisheries 2024). All trainings were designed to be interactive, with group discussions and question and answer sessions. Topics included cattle breeds and their performance, the cattle reproductive cycle, how to select good breeding animals, cow heat detection, and artificial insemination, as well as taking care of pregnant and lactating cows. Materials supporting the training included posters (which remained in cultural centers (CGIAR Research Program on Livestock 2021), and training manuals which were given to each participant (Le et al. 2024 ), see Figures 2 and 3. Particular attention was paid to ensure that both women and men cattle keepers attended the training, though specifically inviting both women and men within households and ensuring that the training location was in a centralized and easy to access location. In addition to the women and men cattle keepers, local animal health care workers attended the training as well.
The respondents were very appreciative of the training, and noted that training of this nature had rarely (If ever) been offered before (Marshall and Le Thi Thanh 2023a).

Activities with artificial insemination service providers
Activities involving both women and men artificial inseminators and from Kinh, Thai and H'Mong ethnic groups aimed to equip them with high-quality skills in artificial insemination (AI) techniques, whilst ensuring AI service delivery was both professional and profitable. Activities comprised comprehensive training in the technical aspects of AI, alongside guidance on business operations. A cooperative was established to facilitate shared access to semen storage facilities, and partnerships were forged with semen suppliers to ensure a steady supply of quality genetics. Additionally, AI service providers were given booklets to track insemination procedures, monitor success rates, and assess the profitability of their services, enhancing both technical proficiency and business sustainability.
Training in the cattle AI technique, certification, and follow-on support
Training of women and men veterinary (animal health) workers and veterinarians on the technique of cattle artificial insemination was achieved through a 21 day training course (Marshall and Huyen 2023b). The course comprised both theoretical and practical sessions. Topics covered during the theoretical sessions included cattle reproduction, cattle breeding, semen including sexed semen, synchronization, heat detection, AI equipment and technique, pregnancy detection, embryo transfer, and reproductive diseases and their treatment. All theoretical sessions were interactive and all trainees were provided with a training manual (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2020a). The practical sessions comprised: examination and practice AI using cow uterus from different culled animals (heifers, cows etc.) provided by the slaughterhouse (Figure 5); practice AI on live cows destined for slaughter; on-farm examination of cows, synchronization and artificial insemination (Figure 6), as well as treatment of reproductive diseases. At the end of the course all trainees were examined for their skills on AI (practical) as well as theoretical understanding (oral examination). Those successfully completing the course were registered with the Animal Husbandry Research and Development Center for Mountainous Zone (ARDC - NIAS) and Issued with a certificate.
Following training, on-going support until project end was provided to the AI service providers through interactions, including field-visits, messages in Zalo group, phone-calls, and video calls, with the AI trainers. (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2024). This on-going support was important in ensuring the AI

Business models studies were undertaken to consider different approaches to sustainable AI service delivery within Son La Province (Bravo et al. 2023a; Bravo et al. 2023b). A key recommendation from the study was a cattle AI service providers cooperative, which would serve multiple purposes including supporting operational capacity, reducing input and equipment costs, acting as a liaison between providers and various stakeholders (such as local authorities, NGOs, input suppliers, and farmers), disseminating technical knowledge related to cattle AI, Improved breeds, and animal husbandry practices. Based on this recommendation a beef-cattle AI service providers co-operative was established, which has played a core role in this model.
The AI co-operative established comprised four members, two men and two women, belonging to the Kinh, Thai and H'Mong ethnic groups. The co-operative leader is the communal veterinary of Hat Lot town, who was an established cattle AI service provider in Mai Son District. Two other members are
Page 10 of 19

communal veterinarians of Chieng Chung and Chieng Luong communes who wanted to become AI service providers for both cows and sows. The fourth member is a director of a beef cooperative and started to do cattle AI service in Muong Bon commune. The membership size of the co-operative was determined based on expected demand for cattle AI within the Chan-Henh project sites. As demand increases, or if the approach is scaled to neighboring sites, the number of members within the co- operative could increase
All co-operative members agreed to, and signed, a common operation regulation. The aim was to ensure that the co-operative supported all members, but with members accruing individual benefits. The regulations covered issues such as: assignment of operational sub-regions assigned to each member, to ensure manageable travel distances; charges for services for uniform pricing; the semen sources to be used; sharing of group costs, for example, shipping fees; recording practices; and other practices such as advise given to farmers on cattle reproduction and AI.
A large (35-litre) liquid nitrogen tank was provided to, and managed through, the co-operative lead. Specially the lead would be responsible for importing liquid nitrogen on a weekly basis and distributing to other co-operative members, as well as semen importation as required, with payment received to cover all costs.
Additionally each members was provided with a small (3 litre) liquid nitrogen tank (to be able to transport semen on the back on motorbikes), an insemination gun (CIDR Bovine applicator) and some consumables (insemination gel, gloves, 5ml cylinders, 18 gauge needles; and synchronization hormones  PGF2 (OvuprostTM), Ovurelin) to help them launch their AI provision businesses.
On semen, experts from NIAS connected the AI co-operative members with four input suppliers for cattle AI (semen and tools) including both state and private ones. The members considered the price, breeds of available semen, way of trading, and the convenience in receiving the inputs. Based on this an individual supplier was selected. Semen is purchased by the co=operative lead as needed, and stored under liquid nitrogen until required by a co-operative member for insemination.
The signing of the common operation regulations and distribution of equipment was undertaken during a workshop (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2024). At this time the AI co-operative members were also introduced to farmers, village heads, leaders of communes, and representatives from the District DARD, provincial DARD; and Agricultural Service Centre.
Communications within the co-operative is facilitated by a Zalo group comprising the AI members as well as NIAS experts on artificial insemination. Discussions have included the sharing of successful AI stories, AI and synchronization issues, diagnosis and treatment of reproductive issues (including by sharing videos and photos), jointly working together to perform AIs when many are being undertaken within a commune, amongst others.
Financial management of the co-operative has been as follows. For the first three months, the project supported the co-operative through the provision of liquid nitrogen, payment of half of the semen and semen transport fees (with the other half paid by the farmer group members receiving the AI), and coverage of re-insemination fees. After this time-period, the co-operative leader has been responsible for purchasing liquid nitrogen, when reimbursement from the co-operative members based on the volumes they use. Note the liquid nitrogen price to the members was set at cost-price, but compensating for liquid nitrogen loss from the main reservoir over time.
Future activities planned by the co-operative include registration at District level, continued promotion of AI, and potentially linking with other livestock development programs to provide AI services. Recording tools
To further support the AI service providers, recording booklets were created to track both artificial inseminations and business profitability. These booklets, developed in both Vietnamese and English, are referred to as the AI Service Provider Recording Booklet on Service Provision (Marshall and Le Thi 2023 c,d) and the AI Service Provider Recording Booklet for Accounting (Marshall and Le Thi, 2023 e,f).
The AI Service Provision booklet enables providers to monitor all activities related to a specific cow and its insemination (Figure 7). It includes detailed records of the client, cow, and AI-related activities, along with dates for follow-up visits and outcomes of the inseminations. Each cow that undergoes insemination has a dedicated double-page spread, facilitating easy visualization of the activities conducted for that cow, such as synchronization, heat detection, insemination, and pregnancy detection. This recording booklet empowers AI service providers to track their clients effectively, plan follow-up visits with ease, and evaluate the outcomes of the artificial insemination process.

Strengthening linkages between the cattle keepers and the AI service providers
Connecting cattle keepers with AI service providers was a crucial aspect of promoting the adoption of cattle artificial insemination. This connection was fostered between farmer groups and AI service providers by having the providers in training sessions on AI (Son La sub-DAH, 2024). Additionally, these service providers took part in village meetings to discuss the benefits of utilizing AI in cattle farming, which helped promote their businesses and offered farmers with a reliable resource for livestock services (https://www.cgiar.org/news-events/news/promoting-the-adoption-of-saplings-innovations- through-village-sharing-events/). A Zalo group has been formed that consists of cattle keepers, AI service providers, AI experts, and researchers from NIAS. This group shares information related to cattle artificial insemination, including topics like cow births, calf care, management of pregnant and lactating cows, and post-calving treatment issues. The discussions are supplemented with pictures and short videos.

# **You are an AI assistant tasked with evaluating research results from CGIAR (Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research) to determine whether they align with and contribute to CGIAR's objectives in nutrition, health, and food security. Your goal is to accurately assign an impact area tag that reflects the relevance and impact of the research on these specific objectives.**

### **Context:**
CGIAR is a global partnership that unites international organizations focused on research for food security. CGIAR has set specific objectives to address global challenges in nutrition, health, and food security, aiming to improve the well-being of populations in developing countries. The research results you will analyze originate from various CGIAR initiatives and projects, particularly in the fields of agriculture, forestry, fisheries, climate, and nutrition.

### **Research Result Components:**
Each research result includes the following details:
- **Title:** A brief title summarizing the research result.
- **Description:** A detailed description of the research result, including methods and findings.
- **Research Abstract:** A summary of key findings and implications (optional).
- **Research Parsed Text:** The parsed text of the research result (optional).

### **Tagging Criteria:**
Assign a nutrition, health, and food security impact tag using the following criteria:

- **0 = Not Targeted:** 
  - The research does not address or contribute to CGIAR's objectives in nutrition, health, or food security.
  - The research is unrelated to these areas, focusing instead on different topics with no significant implications for nutrition, health, or food security.
  - Example: A study focused solely on crop yield improvement without considering its impact on nutrition or food security.

- **1 = Significant:**
  - The research makes a meaningful contribution to CGIAR’s objectives in nutrition, health, or food security, but these are not the primary focus.
  - The research is relevant and provides insights into these areas, but they are secondary to other goals.
  - Example: A study that explores the impact of agricultural practices on food availability, indirectly supporting food security.

- **2 = Principal:**
  - The primary objective of the research is to address and directly impact CGIAR's goals in nutrition, health, or food security.
  - The research would not have been undertaken without the intention to contribute to these specific objectives.
  - Example: A study specifically designed to develop strategies for reducing malnutrition in rural communities by improving access to nutritious foods.

### **Key Objectives Set by CGIAR:**
- **Ending Hunger:** Enabling affordable, healthy diets for the 3 billion people who do not currently have access to safe and nutritious food.
- **Reducing Illness:** Decreasing cases of foodborne illness (600 million annually) and zoonotic diseases (1 billion annually) by one-third.

### **Instructions:**
1. **Analyze the Title and Abstract:** Determine whether the research is related to CGIAR's objectives in nutrition, health, or food security by looking for relevant keywords or phrases, such as “malnutrition,” “food security,” or “public health.”
2. **Review the Description and Parsed Text:** Assess whether the research directly contributes to CGIAR’s objectives in these areas, and how integral these objectives are to the overall study.
3. **Assign the Tag:** Based on the criteria provided, assign the most appropriate tag (0, 1, or 2) that reflects whether the research is related to and impacts CGIAR’s objectives in nutrition, health, and food security.
4. **Provide a Brief Justification:** Explain why you assigned this tag, referencing specific aspects of the research that influenced your decision. Make sure to clarify how the research aligns (or does not align) with CGIAR’s objectives.

### **Important Notes:**
- If the research does not relate to CGIAR's objectives in nutrition, health, or food security, assign a tag of **0** (Not Targeted).
- If the research mentions these areas as important considerations but not the primary focus, assign a tag of **1** (Significant).
- If nutrition, health, or food security are the primary objectives of the research, assign a tag of **2** (Principal).
- When assigning a tag of **2**, ensure that the evidence clearly demonstrates that nutrition, health, or food security objectives were the main goals of the research and fundamental to its design.

Introduction
Agriculture is central to the economy and livelihoods in Vietnams Son La Province, where the mountainous terrain and tropical climate support the cultivation of crops like maize, rice, tea, and various fruits, which are key for both local consumption and trade. Livestock, particularly beef cattle, is an essential component of the agricultural system, providing income through the sale of animals, manure for soil fertility, and draft power for farming. For smallholder farmers, beef cattle production plays a crucial role in their mixed farming systems, contributing significantly to household income and food security. However, farmers face several challenges that limit productivity and profitability. These include limited access to improved cattle genetics, which could enhance meat production, and the prevalence of cattle diseases, which affect herd health and growth. Additionally, the availability of high- quality feed is often constrained, especially during the dry season, impacting cattle growth. Profitability is further hindered by market fluctuations and a lack of organized value chains, which reduce the farmers' ability to secure stable and favorable prices for their cattle. Addressing these challenges through better breeding practices, disease control, improved feeds, and enhanced market access would greatly benefit the farmers and enhance the economic potential of beef cattle production in the region. This has been the aim of the CGIAR Initiative Sustainable Animal Productivity for Livelihoods, Nutrition and Gender Inclusion (SAPLING) operating under the local project name of 'Chan- Henh' in Son La Province (Atieno et al. 2023).
Page 4 of 19

Under Chan-Henh a model was developed to promote use of artificial insemination (AI) in beef cattle. This model was developed in response to concerns from cattle farmers in Son La regarding the difficulty of finding quality breeding cattle and their high price (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2021a). AI has the advantage over natural mating of improving access to high quality genetics, reducing disease spread, and being cost-effective (in comparison to smallholders keeping their own bull). The adoption of beef cattle AI in Son La has traditionally been low (Hammond et al. 2010) due to both the lack of artificial insemination service providers, particularly in more remote locations, as well as lack of farmers awareness on the advantages of the technology (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2021a).
The model to promote the use of beef cattle AI presented here works with women and men AI service providers, women and men beef-cattle keepers, and partners including the Son La Department of Animal Health and Production, Mai Son Department of Agriculture and Rural Development, Mai Son Agricultural Service Center, and Chieng Chung, Chieng Luong, Muong Bon and Hat Lot Communal People Committees. It was tested in the Mai-Son District of Son La Province, where Chan-Henh operates. The model has been successful in both creating business opportunities in AI service provision as well as promoting AI adopting by smallholder cattle keepers, and is recommended for scaling to other locations within Son La Province and northwest Vietnam more broadly.
The Chan-Henh approach
The Chan-Henh project takes an integrated approach to improving beef cattle production and marketing, comprising: capacity building of farmers and service providers on innovations for improved beef cattle genetics, health-care and feeding; a farmers-groups approach for collective action, including on input acquisition and marketing; gender accommodative and transformative approaches to ensure innovation access and benefit is equitable; and a component to Improve nutrition of the producing households (Otieno et al. 2023). It also addresses pig production and marketing, including promotion of pig AI: the pig AI work will be reported separately.
Chan-Henh was Implemented between 2023 and 2024, within four target communes of the Mai Son District (Ching Chung , Ching Lng, Mng Bon and Ht Lt). It was funded through the One CGIAR Initiative Sustainable Animal Productivity for Livelihoods, Nutrition and Gender Inclusion (SAPLING). Permission to undertake the project was granted by the People's Committee of Son La Province on March 25th 2023 according to Decision No. 963/UBND-NC.
The project was co-designed and co-implemented with partners and stakeholders. CGIAR partners included the Alliance of Bioversity International and CIAT (the Alliance) and the International Livestock Research Institute (ILRI) and local partners included the Son La Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (Son La DARD), the Son La Sub-Department of Animal Husbandry (Son La Sub-DAH), the National Institute of Animal Sciences of Vietnam (NIAS), the National Institute of Veterinary Research (NIVR), the Northern Mountainous Agriculture and Forestry Sciences Institute (NOMAFSI), the Vietnam National University of Agriculture (VNUA) and the National institute of Nutrition (NIN).
A key element of Chan-Henh was the use of farmer groups for improved access of the smallholder farmers to input and output markets, as well as being a forum for capacity development and co-create of solutions to issues pertaining to pig and cattle keeping. Given the inefficient function of the existing farmer groups engaged in cattle and pig production in Mai Son District (in terms of economic and financial sustainability, service offers, marketing connection and trading capacity (Cuong et al. 2023), Chan-Henh focused on developing and implementing strategic plans for upgrading the functioning and capacities of the existing farmer groups, and used that lesson to support the establishment and efficient operation of new farmer groups. Since 2023, SAPLING has been assisting eight farmer groups, comprising 120 members.
Page 5 of 19

The model for promotion of beef cattle artificial insemination
Overview
The model to promote cattle artificial insemination (AI) in northwest Vietnam involved: (a) building the capacity of smallholder cattle keepers on cattle breeds, breeding and artificial insemination; (b) training AI service providers in both the technical aspects of artificial insemination as well as agri-business skills and organizing these into a co-operative for shared access to centrally-located semen storage facilities; and (c) facilitating linkages between the cattle keepers and the AI service providers. A schema for the model is given in Figure 1 and more details are given below. Various resources supporting implementation of the model are freely available, as summarized in Box 1.

Activities with smallholder cattle keepers
Activities with smallholder women and men cattle keepers were aimed at increasing their capacity on, and improving their attitude towards, cattle AI. The activities comprised training on beef cattle breeds, breeding and AI, examining and treating reproductive diseases, as well as exposure to cattle AI through demonstration farms.
Training of cattle keepers on cattle breeds, breeding and AI
Training on cattle breeding, breeds and artificial insemination was achieved both through community workshop and trainings held within farmer groups. The training were a day in length and conducted by an expert team from NIAS (for the community workshops (Marshall and Le Thi Thanh 2023a) and by the Son La sub-DAH team for the farmer-group members (Son La Sub-department of Livestock Production, Animal Health and Fisheries 2024). All trainings were designed to be interactive, with group discussions and question and answer sessions. Topics included cattle breeds and their performance, the cattle reproductive cycle, how to select good breeding animals, cow heat detection, and artificial insemination, as well as taking care of pregnant and lactating cows. Materials supporting the training included posters (which remained in cultural centers (CGIAR Research Program on Livestock 2021), and training manuals which were given to each participant (Le et al. 2024 ), see Figures 2 and 3. Particular attention was paid to ensure that both women and men cattle keepers attended the training, though specifically inviting both women and men within households and ensuring that the training location was in a centralized and easy to access location. In addition to the women and men cattle keepers, local animal health care workers attended the training as well.
The respondents were very appreciative of the training, and noted that training of this nature had rarely (If ever) been offered before (Marshall and Le Thi Thanh 2023a).

Activities with artificial insemination service providers
Activities involving both women and men artificial inseminators and from Kinh, Thai and H'Mong ethnic groups aimed to equip them with high-quality skills in artificial insemination (AI) techniques, whilst ensuring AI service delivery was both professional and profitable. Activities comprised comprehensive training in the technical aspects of AI, alongside guidance on business operations. A cooperative was established to facilitate shared access to semen storage facilities, and partnerships were forged with semen suppliers to ensure a steady supply of quality genetics. Additionally, AI service providers were given booklets to track insemination procedures, monitor success rates, and assess the profitability of their services, enhancing both technical proficiency and business sustainability.
Training in the cattle AI technique, certification, and follow-on support
Training of women and men veterinary (animal health) workers and veterinarians on the technique of cattle artificial insemination was achieved through a 21 day training course (Marshall and Huyen 2023b). The course comprised both theoretical and practical sessions. Topics covered during the theoretical sessions included cattle reproduction, cattle breeding, semen including sexed semen, synchronization, heat detection, AI equipment and technique, pregnancy detection, embryo transfer, and reproductive diseases and their treatment. All theoretical sessions were interactive and all trainees were provided with a training manual (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2020a). The practical sessions comprised: examination and practice AI using cow uterus from different culled animals (heifers, cows etc.) provided by the slaughterhouse (Figure 5); practice AI on live cows destined for slaughter; on-farm examination of cows, synchronization and artificial insemination (Figure 6), as well as treatment of reproductive diseases. At the end of the course all trainees were examined for their skills on AI (practical) as well as theoretical understanding (oral examination). Those successfully completing the course were registered with the Animal Husbandry Research and Development Center for Mountainous Zone (ARDC - NIAS) and Issued with a certificate.
Following training, on-going support until project end was provided to the AI service providers through interactions, including field-visits, messages in Zalo group, phone-calls, and video calls, with the AI trainers. (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2024). This on-going support was important in ensuring the AI

Business models studies were undertaken to consider different approaches to sustainable AI service delivery within Son La Province (Bravo et al. 2023a; Bravo et al. 2023b). A key recommendation from the study was a cattle AI service providers cooperative, which would serve multiple purposes including supporting operational capacity, reducing input and equipment costs, acting as a liaison between providers and various stakeholders (such as local authorities, NGOs, input suppliers, and farmers), disseminating technical knowledge related to cattle AI, Improved breeds, and animal husbandry practices. Based on this recommendation a beef-cattle AI service providers co-operative was established, which has played a core role in this model.
The AI co-operative established comprised four members, two men and two women, belonging to the Kinh, Thai and H'Mong ethnic groups. The co-operative leader is the communal veterinary of Hat Lot town, who was an established cattle AI service provider in Mai Son District. Two other members are
Page 10 of 19

communal veterinarians of Chieng Chung and Chieng Luong communes who wanted to become AI service providers for both cows and sows. The fourth member is a director of a beef cooperative and started to do cattle AI service in Muong Bon commune. The membership size of the co-operative was determined based on expected demand for cattle AI within the Chan-Henh project sites. As demand increases, or if the approach is scaled to neighboring sites, the number of members within the co- operative could increase
All co-operative members agreed to, and signed, a common operation regulation. The aim was to ensure that the co-operative supported all members, but with members accruing individual benefits. The regulations covered issues such as: assignment of operational sub-regions assigned to each member, to ensure manageable travel distances; charges for services for uniform pricing; the semen sources to be used; sharing of group costs, for example, shipping fees; recording practices; and other practices such as advise given to farmers on cattle reproduction and AI.
A large (35-litre) liquid nitrogen tank was provided to, and managed through, the co-operative lead. Specially the lead would be responsible for importing liquid nitrogen on a weekly basis and distributing to other co-operative members, as well as semen importation as required, with payment received to cover all costs.
Additionally each members was provided with a small (3 litre) liquid nitrogen tank (to be able to transport semen on the back on motorbikes), an insemination gun (CIDR Bovine applicator) and some consumables (insemination gel, gloves, 5ml cylinders, 18 gauge needles; and synchronization hormones  PGF2 (OvuprostTM), Ovurelin) to help them launch their AI provision businesses.
On semen, experts from NIAS connected the AI co-operative members with four input suppliers for cattle AI (semen and tools) including both state and private ones. The members considered the price, breeds of available semen, way of trading, and the convenience in receiving the inputs. Based on this an individual supplier was selected. Semen is purchased by the co=operative lead as needed, and stored under liquid nitrogen until required by a co-operative member for insemination.
The signing of the common operation regulations and distribution of equipment was undertaken during a workshop (Le Thi Thanh and Marshall 2024). At this time the AI co-operative members were also introduced to farmers, village heads, leaders of communes, and representatives from the District DARD, provincial DARD; and Agricultural Service Centre.
Communications within the co-operative is facilitated by a Zalo group comprising the AI members as well as NIAS experts on artificial insemination. Discussions have included the sharing of successful AI stories, AI and synchronization issues, diagnosis and treatment of reproductive issues (including by sharing videos and photos), jointly working together to perform AIs when many are being undertaken within a commune, amongst others.
Financial management of the co-operative has been as follows. For the first three months, the project supported the co-operative through the provision of liquid nitrogen, payment of half of the semen and semen transport fees (with the other half paid by the farmer group members receiving the AI), and coverage of re-insemination fees. After this time-period, the co-operative leader has been responsible for purchasing liquid nitrogen, when reimbursement from the co-operative members based on the volumes they use. Note the liquid nitrogen price to the members was set at cost-price, but compensating for liquid nitrogen loss from the main reservoir over time.
Future activities planned by the co-operative include registration at District level, continued promotion of AI, and potentially linking with other livestock development programs to provide AI services. Recording tools
To further support the AI service providers, recording booklets were created to track both artificial inseminations and business profitability. These booklets, developed in both Vietnamese and English, are referred to as the AI Service Provider Recording Booklet on Service Provision (Marshall and Le Thi 2023 c,d) and the AI Service Provider Recording Booklet for Accounting (Marshall and Le Thi, 2023 e,f).
The AI Service Provision booklet enables providers to monitor all activities related to a specific cow and its insemination (Figure 7). It includes detailed records of the client, cow, and AI-related activities, along with dates for follow-up visits and outcomes of the inseminations. Each cow that undergoes insemination has a dedicated double-page spread, facilitating easy visualization of the activities conducted for that cow, such as synchronization, heat detection, insemination, and pregnancy detection. This recording booklet empowers AI service providers to track their clients effectively, plan follow-up visits with ease, and evaluate the outcomes of the artificial insemination process.

Training in agri-business skills.
The AI service providers were additionally trained in agri-business skills with the aim of increasing their professionalism and ensuring business profitability.
The training course focused on 3 contents (Le et al. 2024):
 Training on business plans. This was to (i) assess the current status of AI service provision of the group; ii) enhance the group's organizational structure and responsibilities; iii) establish revenue targets for both the group and its individual members; iv) create a comprehensive business plan for the group; and v) finalize the pricing list for services offered. This was to (i) assess the current status of AI service provision of the group; ii) enhance the group's organizational structure and responsibilities; iii) establish revenue targets for both the group and its individual members; iv) create a comprehensive business plan for the group; and v) finalize the pricing list for services offered.
 Training on marketing and sale skills to assist each group member in developing their marketing and sales strategies to achieve their individual and group sales goals. Furthermore individual coaching were provided to assist each group member in developing promotional materials for advertising their services in the community using platforms such as Zalo, Facebook, and local meetings (Figure 9).
 Monthly group meetings were held to review progress and make necessary adjustments to the business plan.

Strengthening linkages between the cattle keepers and the AI service providers
Connecting cattle keepers with AI service providers was a crucial aspect of promoting the adoption of cattle artificial insemination. This connection was fostered between farmer groups and AI service providers by having the providers in training sessions on AI (Son La sub-DAH, 2024). Additionally, these service providers took part in village meetings to discuss the benefits of utilizing AI in cattle farming, which helped promote their businesses and offered farmers with a reliable resource for livestock services (https://www.cgiar.org/news-events/news/promoting-the-adoption-of-saplings-innovations- through-village-sharing-events/). A Zalo group has been formed that consists of cattle keepers, AI service providers, AI experts, and researchers from NIAS. This group shares information related to cattle artificial insemination, including topics like cow births, calf care, management of pregnant and lactating cows, and post-calving treatment issues. The discussions are supplemented with pictures and short videos.
The AI service providers expressed that these linkages were essential for building relationships with potential clients, while farmers appreciated knowing their service provider and having direct contact with them.
Gender considerations
Women's contributions to the agricultural sector are crucial, and one of the key objectives of the Chan Henh project was to enhance their inclusion (Atieno et al. 2023). # **You are an AI assistant tasked with evaluating research results from CGIAR (Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research) to determine whether they align with and contribute to CGIAR's objectives in nutrition, health, and food security. Your goal is to accurately assign an impact area tag that reflects the relevance and impact of the research on these specific objectives.**

### **Context:**
CGIAR is a global partnership that unites international organizations focused on research for food security. CGIAR has set specific objectives to address global challenges in nutrition, health, and food security, aiming to improve the well-being of populations in developing countries. The research results you will analyze originate from various CGIAR initiatives and projects, particularly in the fields of agriculture, forestry, fisheries, climate, and nutrition.

### **Research Result Components:**
Each research result includes the following details:
- **Title:** A brief title summarizing the research result.
- **Description:** A detailed description of the research result, including methods and findings.
- **Research Abstract:** A summary of key findings and implications (optional).
- **Research Parsed Text:** The parsed text of the research result (optional).

### **Tagging Criteria:**
Assign a nutrition, health, and food security impact tag using the following criteria:

- **0 = Not Targeted:** 
  - The research does not address or contribute to CGIAR's objectives in nutrition, health, or food security.
  - The research is unrelated to these areas, focusing instead on different topics with no significant implications for nutrition, health, or food security.
  - Example: A study focused solely on crop yield improvement without considering its impact on nutrition or food security.

- **1 = Significant:**
  - The research makes a meaningful contribution to CGIAR’s objectives in nutrition, health, or food security, but these are not the primary focus.
  - The research is relevant and provides insights into these areas, but they are secondary to other goals.
  - Example: A study that explores the impact of agricultural practices on food availability, indirectly supporting food security.

- **2 = Principal:**
  - The primary objective of the research is to address and directly impact CGIAR's goals in nutrition, health, or food security.
  - The research would not have been undertaken without the intention to contribute to these specific objectives.
  - Example: A study specifically designed to develop strategies for reducing malnutrition in rural communities by improving access to nutritious foods.

### **Key Objectives Set by CGIAR:**
- **Ending Hunger:** Enabling affordable, healthy diets for the 3 billion people who do not currently have access to safe and nutritious food.
- **Reducing Illness:** Decreasing cases of foodborne illness (600 million annually) and zoonotic diseases (1 billion annually) by one-third.

### **Instructions:**
1. **Analyze the Title and Abstract:** Determine whether the research is related to CGIAR's objectives in nutrition, health, or food security by looking for relevant keywords or phrases, such as “malnutrition,” “food security,” or “public health.”
2. **Review the Description and Parsed Text:** Assess whether the research directly contributes to CGIAR’s objectives in these areas, and how integral these objectives are to the overall study.
3. **Assign the Tag:** Based on the criteria provided, assign the most appropriate tag (0, 1, or 2) that reflects whether the research is related to and impacts CGIAR’s objectives in nutrition, health, and food security.
4. **Provide a Brief Justification:** Explain why you assigned this tag, referencing specific aspects of the research that influenced your decision. Make sure to clarify how the research aligns (or does not align) with CGIAR’s objectives.

### **Important Notes:**
- If the research does not relate to CGIAR's objectives in nutrition, health, or food security, assign a tag of **0** (Not Targeted).
- If the research mentions these areas as important considerations but not the primary focus, assign a tag of **1** (Significant).
- If nutrition, health, or food security are the primary objectives of the research, assign a tag of **2** (Principal).
- When assigning a tag of **2**, ensure that the evidence clearly demonstrates that nutrition, health, or food security objectives were the main goals of the research and fundamental to its design.

### **Structured Output Format:**
